document.docAuthor: Shepard, William D. & Sites, Robert W.
document.masterDocTitle: Larval Psephenidae (Coleoptera: Byrrhoidea) of Thailand: Annotated List and Illustrated Key to Genera

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Larval Psephenidae (Coleoptera: Byrrhoidea) of Thailand: Annotated List and Illustrated Key to Genera

heading.emphasis: KEY TO THE SUBFAMILIES AND GENERA OF LARVAL

subSubSection.paragraph:
(Larvae of
Afropsephenoides Basilewsky
,
Heteropsephenoides Jeng and Jäch
,
Micreubrianax Pic
, and
Psephenoides Gahan
are undescribed; one undescribed larva in Eubrianacinae is in our collections.)

paragraph.keyLead: 1. Gills concealed by an operculum on the 9 th abdominal sternum ( Fig. 10 ) ................. 2
1 ʹ . Gills exposed on abdominal venter ( Fig. 11 ); operculum absent ............................... 3

2. Ninth abdominal segment surrounded by paratergites of the previous segment(s) ( Fig. 12 ).
Psephenoidinae
........................... 4

2 ʹ . Ninth abdominal segment not surrounded by paratergites of the previous segment(s) ( Fig. 13 ).
Eubriinae
................................... 5

3. Gills with branches arising from a central stalk ( Fig. 14 ).
Psepheninae
................... ..................
Mataeopsephus Waterhouse

3 ʹ . Gills palmate ( Fig. 11 ).
Eubrianacinae
…. 10

4. Setae on venter apically stellate ( Fig. 15 ); cephalic plate short and moderately thin ( Fig. 16 ) ....................
Sinopsephenoides Yang

4 ʹ . Setae on venter apically rounded; cephalic plate usually absent, but if present, very thin and elongate ( Fig. 39 ) ............................ .......................
all other Psephenoidinae

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 1–3. Larvae of Eubrianacinae . 1) Genus morphologically similar to
Eubrianax
; 2)
Jinbrianax
; 3)
Jaechanax
. app = abdominal posterior plates; cl = costal lines; cp = cephalic plate; cpl = closed periocellar line; gap = gap between abdominal paratergites 6 and 7; ipl = incomplete periocellar line; para = paratergites. All figures from
Lee et al. (2007)
.

paragraph.keyLead: 5 ʹ . Ninth abdominal segment emarginate or bifurcate posteriorly ( Fig. 18 ) .................. 7

6. Paratergites apically truncate; 9 th abdominal segment as long as wide ( Fig. 35 ) ............ ...................
Granuleubria Jäch and Lee

6 ʹ . Paratergites apically acicular; 9 th abdominal segment 2X longer than wide ( Fig. 33 ) .. ... ....................
Homoeogenus Waterhouse

7. Meso- and metathoracic paratergites truncate laterally ( Fig. 19 ) .................................. ....................
Microeubria Lee and Yang
7 ʹ . Meso- and metathoracic paratergites acicular laterally ( Fig. 20 ) ................................ 8

8. Prothoracic paratergites extending from middle of lateral margins ( Fig. 21 ) ........... .......
Dicranopselaphus Guérin-Méneville
8 ʹ . Prothoracic paratergites extending from posterolateral corners ( Figs. 34, 36 ) ……… 9

9. Body ovate, usually with color pattern ( Fig. 36 ) ...............
Schinostethus Waterhouse

9 ʹ . Body elongate, usually concolorous ( Fig. 34 ) .............................
Macroeubria Pic
10 ʹ . Abdominal paratergites 6 and 7 contiguous ( Fig. 2 ) ........................................... 12

11. Periocellar lines present ( Figs. 2, 3 ) .......... .............
Jaechanax Lee, Satô, and Yang

11 ʹ . Periocellar lines absent ( Fig. 1 ) ................ .............
Odontanax Lee, Satô, and Yang

12. Periocellar lines complete ( Fig. 3 ); costal lines present ( Figs. 1–3 ) ......................... ............
Mubrianax Lee, Satô, and Yang

12 ʹ . Periocellar lines incomplete ( Fig. 2 ); costal lines absent .......................................... .............
Jinbrianax Lee, Satô, and Yang
